core_claim: Lake Hillier in Australia remains permanently pink due to natural causes, and unlike other pink lakes, it maintains its vibrant color even when water is removed.

supporting_details.location: Middle Island, Recherche Archipelago, Western Australia
supporting_details.cause: Dunaliella salina microalgae, halobacteria, and high salt concentration
supporting_details.unique_property: Retains pink color even in glass containers

source_citation: Parks and Wildlife Service of Western Australia; Research published in PLOS ONE journal by Amatya et al. (2017)
why_strange: A naturally occurring bubblegum-pink lake that defies the usual temporary coloration patterns of other saline lakes

core_claim: The Catatumbo Lightning in Venezuela is the world's most consistent thunderstorm, occurring 140-160 nights per year, 10 hours per night, with up to 280 strikes per hour, for centuries.

supporting_details.location: Where Catatumbo River meets Lake Maracaibo, Venezuela
supporting_details.frequency: Up to 280 lightning strikes per hour
supporting_details.duration: 140-160 nights per year, 10 hours per night
supporting_details.unique_property: Generates 1.2 million lightning strikes annually and is visible from 400km away

source_citation: Guinness World Records (2013); NASA Earth Observatory; Research by the Center for Scientific Research of Maracaibo Lake
why_strange: A perpetual lightning storm that has occurred in the same location for centuries with no seasonal interruption

core_claim: The Hessdalen Lights in Norway are unexplained luminous phenomena that have been scientifically monitored since 1984, appearing as floating, pulsating lights that can last for over an hour.

supporting_details.date: First documented surge in 1981, ongoing observations since
supporting_details.frequency: Peak of 20 observations per week in 1980s, now 10-20 per year
supporting_details.characteristics: Yellow/white/blue lights floating 3-5 meters above ground

source_citation: Project Hessdalen scientific monitoring station; Papers published in Journal of Scientific Exploration; Østfold University College research
why_strange: Despite decades of scientific monitoring with sophisticated equipment, these naturally occurring lights remain unexplained by conventional physics

core_claim: Blood Falls in Antarctica is a blood-red waterfall flowing from Taylor Glacier, caused by iron-rich hypersaline water from an ancient subglacial lake that has been isolated for at least 1.5 million years.

supporting_details.date: Discovered in 1911 by geologist Griffith Taylor
supporting_details.age: Water source estimated to be 1.5-2 million years old
supporting_details.composition: Water with 3x ocean's salinity and high iron content
supporting_details.unique_property: Contains ancient microbes that survive without oxygen or sunlight

source_citation: Journal of Glaciology (2017); Nature Communications research by Mikucki et al. (2009); U.S. National Science Foundation Antarctic Program
why_strange: A blood-red waterfall flowing from pristine white ice, containing microbes that have evolved in isolation for millions of years

core_claim: In Venezuela, a lightning storm known as 'Relámpago del Catatumbo' occurs up to 260 nights a year, producing over a million lightning strikes annually in the same spot.

supporting_details.location: Mouth of the Catatumbo River, Lake Maracaibo, Venezuela
supporting_details.duration: Typically 10 hours per night, up to 280 lightning strikes per hour

source_citation: NASA Earth Observatory; Guinness World Records (2014)
why_strange: It's the most persistent lightning hotspot on Earth, defying normal weather patterns

core_claim: In 2001, it rained fish in the small town of Yoro, Honduras—a phenomenon that reportedly occurs almost annually during strong storms.

supporting_details.fish_type: Small, silver freshwater fish found flopping on streets after storms

source_citation: National Geographic; BBC News (2001); Smithsonian Magazine
why_strange: Fish fall from the sky miles inland, baffling scientists for decades

core_claim: The Sailing Stones of Death Valley move across the desert floor on their own, leaving long trails behind them—without human or animal intervention.

supporting_details.location: Racetrack Playa, Death Valley National Park, California, USA
supporting_details.scientific_explanation: Thin ice sheets and light winds cause stones to slide

source_citation: NASA Earth Observatory; Science journal (2014 study by Norris et al.)
why_strange: Massive rocks appear to move by themselves in a dry desert with no visible force
